revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Mike O'Brien | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Michael Patrick O'Brien | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|6|22}} | birth_place = [[Blissfield, Michigan]], United States | active = | medium = Television, film, acting, writing | spouse = |alma_mater=[[University of Michigan]] | genre = [[Improvisational comedy]], [[sketch comedy]] | notable_work = ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''
''[[A.P. Bio]]'' }} '''Michael Patrick{{cite news|first=Bradford|last=Evans|title='SNL' Writer Michael Patrick O'Brien Is Also Joining the Cast as a Featured Player|work=Splitsider|date=August 23, 2013|accessdate=August 29, 2014|url=http://splitsider.com/2013/08/snl-writer-michael-patrick-obrien-is-also-joining-the-cast-as-a-featured-player/}} O'Brien''' (born June 22, 1976),{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/about/bio/cast/mike-obrien/795952/ |title=Mike O'Brien Bio | Featured Player | Saturday Night Live |publisher=NBC |archivedate=2013-10-15 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131015044903/http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/about/bio/cast/mike-obrien/795952/ |accessdate=October 7, 2013}} is an American actor, writer, and comedian known for his work as a writer and short filmmaker on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. He is the creator of the 2018 [[NBC]] comedy series ''[[A.P. Bio]]''. ==Career == O'Brien attended the [[University of Michigan]], where he majored in film-video and was the founder and editor of a monthly comedy newspaper named ''The Anti-Daily''.{{cite web |title= 'Alumni Profile: SNL's Mike O'Brien' |url= http://www.michigandaily.com/blog/wire/alumni-profile-snl-featured-player-mike-obrien |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150402091326/http://www.michigandaily.com/blog/wire/alumni-profile-snl-featured-player-mike-obrien |archivedate= April 2, 2015 |df= mdy-all }} O'Brien moved to Chicago and began taking improv and sketch classes. At iO Chicago he performed with a group called The Reckoning (2001–present). He trained at the Second City in Chicago, eventually joining the company’s mainstage, where he performed for one year as a part of "America: All Better".{{cite web |title= 'IO Profile' |url= http://iowatercooler.com/mike-obrien/}} In 2015, O'Brien released his sketch comedy album ''Tasty Radio'', featuring many of the cast members and writers he worked with on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. In 2018, he created the comedy series ''[[A.P. Bio]]'', starring [[Glenn Howerton]] and [[Patton Oswalt]]. O'Brien's former ''SNL'' colleagues [[Lorne Michaels]] and [[Seth Meyers]] are also executive producers on the show. The series premiered on February 1, 2018. ==''Saturday Night Live''== O'Brien worked as a staff writer on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' for seven seasons, joining the show in 2009, and also appeared as a featured player for the [[Saturday Night Live (season 39)|2013–14 season]].{{cite web |title= Alumni Profile: SNL Featured Player Mike O'Brien |first= Claire |last= Bryan |work= The Michigan Daily |date= December 5, 2013 |url= https://www.michigandaily.com/blog/wire/alumni-profile-snl-featured-player-mike-obrien |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131215181117/https://www.michigandaily.com/blog/wire/alumni-profile-snl-featured-player-mike-obrien |archivedate= December 15, 2013 |df= mdy-all }}{{cite web | url = http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/about/bio/mike-obrien | title = Mike O'Brien, Featured Player | publisher = [[NBC Universal]] | accessdate = 2014-06-24 }} After his sole season as a featured player, he left the cast but continued to write for the show in his final season from 2014 to 2015.{{cite web|title=Mike O'Brien Will Not Return As SNL Player|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/09/15/mike-obrien-will-not-return-as-an-snl-player-this-season}} Some of O'Brien's sketches include "Monster Pals" starring James Franco as well as "Puppet Class" starring Bill Hader. His short films "Grow a Guy" and "The Jay-Z Story" were each given the title card, "A Mike O'Brien Picture" in season 40.{{cite web|title=Breakding Down Each Cast Member's Contribution to SNL Season 39 |url=http://splitsider.com/2014/05/looking-at-the-cast-of-snl-season-39/}} After leaving the writing staff in season 41, O'Brien has continued to contribute short films under the title, ''A Mike O'Brien Picture''. ==''7 Minutes in Heaven with Mike O'Brien''== In 2011, O'Brien introduced ''7 Minutes in Heaven with Mike O'Brien'', a comedy routine in which he interviews celebrities in a closet and closes by trying to kiss the celebrity.{{cite web | url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/popcandy/post/2011/08/watch-stars-talk-not-make-out-on-7-minutes-in-heaven/1#.UMP_74NQVR4 | title=Watch stars talk (not make out) on '7 Minutes in Heaven' |work=USA Today |last=Matheson |first=Whitney| date=1 August 2011}}{{cite web |title= 'Seven Minutes in Heaven': The not-so-fine art of the awkward kiss |work= Chicago Tribune |first= Christopher |last= Borrelli |date= April 4, 2012 |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-04-04/entertainment/ct-ent-0405-seven-minutes-in-heaven-20120404_1_snl-web-success-improv }}{{cite news |title= SNL Writer Mike O'Brien Talks Getting Trapped in the Closet with Kristen Wiig on New Show |work= Huffington Post |date= July 31, 2011 |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/hulucom/mike-obrien-kristen-wiig_b_913797.html }} ==''Tasty Radio''== In 2015, Mike released a comedy sketch album entitled ''Tasty Radio'', which features [[Bill Hader]], [[Fred Armisen]], [[Jason Sudeikis]], [[Vanessa Bayer]], [[Seth Meyers]], [[John Mulaney]], [[Jorma Taccone]], [[John Lutz]] and [[Scarlett Johansson]].{{cite web | url=http://splitsider.com/2015/10/mike-obriens-sketch-comedy-album-tasty-radio-is-out-today/|title=Mike O’Brien’s Sketch Comedy Album "Tasty Radio" Is Out Today|first=Megh|last=Wright|date=October 30, 2015|website=Splitsider.com}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|3653190}} {{authority control}}
